metadata.name: TOAST First Aid Reference
metadata.disclaimer: This information is general first aid guidance and is not a substitute for professional medical training or care. Always seek qualified medical help as soon as it is available.

entries.title: Severe Bleeding
entries.summary: Control heavy bleeding from a wound when help is not immediately available.
steps: Check that the area is safe before approaching the injured person.
Have the person lie down if possible to reduce the risk of fainting.
Expose the wound by carefully removing or cutting away clothing around it.
Place a clean cloth, bandage, or any clean absorbent material directly over the wound.
Apply firm, steady pressure with your hand or hands directly on the wound.
If blood soaks through the cloth, place additional cloth or pads on top and continue pressing. Do not remove the original cloth.
If the wound is on a limb and there is no suspected fracture, gently raise the limb above the level of the heart while maintaining pressure.
Continue direct pressure for at least 10–15 minutes without checking too often; lifting the cloth can restart bleeding.
If bleeding remains heavy and life-threatening despite firm direct pressure, apply a tourniquet if you have one and know how to use it.
Place the tourniquet 5–7 cm (2–3 inches) above the wound, between the wound and the heart, and never directly over a joint.
Tighten the tourniquet until the bleeding stops or significantly slows. It will usually be painful when effective.
Secure the tourniquet so it cannot loosen and note the time it was applied.
After bleeding is controlled, cover the person with a blanket or clothing to keep them warm and monitor for signs of shock such as pale skin, rapid pulse, or confusion.
Seek professional medical care as soon as it becomes available, even if the bleeding appears controlled.
do_not: Do not remove blood-soaked cloths already on the wound; add new layers on top instead.
Do not apply a tourniquet unless bleeding is severe and not controlled by direct pressure.
Do not place a tourniquet directly over a joint or over sharp objects or debris.
Do not loosen a properly applied tourniquet unless instructed by a medical professional.
watch_for: Continued heavy bleeding despite direct pressure.
Signs of shock: pale or clammy skin, rapid breathing, weakness, confusion, or loss of consciousness.
Loss of feeling or movement below the tourniquet site.
notes: In a survival situation, a tourniquet can be made from a wide band of cloth and a rigid object used as a windlass to twist and tighten.
If professional help is delayed, monitor the person’s breathing and level of responsiveness frequently.

entries.title: Cardiac Arrest and CPR
entries.summary: Provide chest compressions when a person is not breathing and has no signs of circulation.
steps: Ensure the area is safe for you and the person.
Check responsiveness by speaking loudly and gently shaking their shoulder.
If there is no response, place the person on their back on a firm surface.
Open the airway by tilting the head back slightly and lifting the chin.
Look for normal breathing for no more than 10 seconds: watch the chest, listen for breath sounds, feel for air on your cheek.
If the person is not breathing or only gasping, begin chest compressions immediately.
Kneel beside the person’s chest. Place the heel of one hand in the center of the chest on the lower half of the breastbone, between the nipples.
Place your other hand on top of the first and interlock your fingers. Keep your arms straight and shoulders directly over your hands.
Press down hard and fast, compressing the chest about 5 cm (2 inches) in adults, allowing full recoil between compressions.
Aim for a rate of 100–120 compressions per minute (about two compressions per second).

If you are trained and willing to give rescue breaths: after 30 compressions, open the airway (head tilt–chin lift), pinch the nose closed, seal your mouth over theirs, and give 1 steady breath over 1 second. Watch for chest rise.
Give a second breath, then immediately resume chest compressions for another 30 compressions.
If you are not trained or do not wish to give rescue breaths, continue hands-only CPR with continuous chest compressions.
Continue CPR until the person shows clear signs of life (such as normal breathing or movement), you are physically unable to continue, or trained help becomes available.
If an automated external defibrillator (AED) becomes available, follow its voice prompts while continuing CPR as instructed.
do_not: Do not spend more than 10 seconds checking for breathing or pulse if you are not trained.
Do not interrupt chest compressions for more than a few seconds unless absolutely necessary.
Do not give breaths if you are not comfortable or trained; continuous compressions are still helpful.
watch_for: Return of normal breathing or purposeful movement.
Coughing or attempts to speak, which can indicate improved circulation.
Changes in skin color, such as improvement from blue or gray toward normal tone.
notes: High-quality chest compressions are more important than perfect technique; focus on depth, rate, and full chest recoil.
If there are multiple rescuers, take turns doing compressions every 2 minutes to prevent fatigue.

entries.title: Choking (Adult or Child)
entries.summary: Help a person who has a blocked airway and cannot breathe effectively.
steps: Quickly assess if the person can speak, cough, or breathe.
If the person is able to cough or talk, encourage them to keep coughing to try to clear the obstruction, and stay close to monitor.
If the person cannot speak, cough, or breathe, treat it as a severe airway obstruction.
Stand slightly behind and to the side of the person. Support their chest with one hand and lean them forward.
Deliver 5 firm back blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of your hand, checking after each blow to see if the object is expelled.
If the obstruction is not cleared, stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand and place it just above the person’s navel (belly button) but well below the breastbone.
Grasp your fist with your other hand and pull sharply inward and upward, performing abdominal thrusts.
Give up to 5 abdominal thrusts, checking after each thrust to see if the object is expelled.
Alternate between 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until the object is cleared or the person becomes unresponsive.
If the person becomes unresponsive, gently lower them to the ground and begin CPR, starting with chest compressions.
Each time you open the airway to give breaths during CPR, look into the mouth for a visible object and remove it if you can see it and reach it easily.
Continue efforts until normal breathing returns or help becomes available.
do_not: Do not perform blind finger sweeps in the mouth; this can push the object deeper into the airway.
Do not slap the person on the back while they are upright and not leaning forward, as this can drive the object deeper.
Do not perform abdominal thrusts on infants or on pregnant individuals; special techniques are required for those cases.
watch_for: Sudden ability to cough, speak, or breathe, which suggests the obstruction is cleared.
Worsening signs such as bluish skin, loss of consciousness, or weak or absent breathing.
Changes in responsiveness; be ready to start CPR if the person collapses.
notes: After a severe choking episode, even if the object is expelled, the person may have internal injury and should be evaluated by a medical professional when possible.
For infants and pregnant individuals, use modified techniques; this guide is focused on adults and older children.

entries.title: Severe Allergic Reaction (Anaphylaxis)
entries.summary: Recognize and respond to a life-threatening allergic reaction.
steps: Look for signs of a severe allergic reaction: trouble breathing, wheezing, swelling of the face, lips, or tongue, hives, vomiting, or a feeling of impending doom.
If the person has a prescribed epinephrine auto-injector, retrieve it immediately.
Remove the auto-injector from its case and follow the instructions on the label.
Hold the injector firmly in your fist with the needle end pointing downward, keeping fingers away from both ends.
Place the needle end against the outer thigh, halfway between the hip and knee. The injection can be given through clothing if necessary.
Press the injector firmly into the thigh until you hear or feel a click, and hold it there for the recommended time (usually several seconds) to deliver the medication.
Remove the injector and massage the injection site for about 10 seconds.
Have the person lie down or sit in a comfortable position. If breathing is easier when sitting upright, support them in that position.
Loosen tight clothing, especially around the neck and chest.
Monitor breathing and level of consciousness continuously.
If symptoms such as difficulty breathing, swelling, or dizziness return or do not improve after 5–10 minutes, and a second dose is available, give a second injection in the other thigh if possible.
Keep the person warm and calm while awaiting or traveling to medical care.
do_not: Do not delay epinephrine use when severe allergic reaction is suspected; it is more dangerous to wait.
Do not inject epinephrine into the hands, fingers, or buttocks; the outer thigh is the safest and most effective site.
Do not allow the person to stand or walk if they feel faint or weak; this can worsen low blood pressure.
watch_for: Rapid improvement in breathing and reduction of swelling after epinephrine.
Rebound symptoms such as returning difficulty breathing, hives, or swelling.
Signs of shock: pale or cool skin, rapid pulse, weakness, or confusion.
notes: Even when symptoms improve after epinephrine, professional evaluation is important because symptoms can return hours later.
If no epinephrine is available, focus on airway support, calming the person, and getting to medical care as quickly as possible.

entries.title: Shock
entries.summary: Manage a person showing signs of shock from injury or illness.
steps: Recognize signs of shock: pale or clammy skin, rapid pulse, fast or shallow breathing, weakness, confusion, or fainting.
Help the person lie flat on their back if possible.
If there is no suspected head, neck, back, or leg injury, raise the legs 20–30 cm (8–12 inches) to improve blood flow to the core.
Keep the person warm by covering them with a blanket, coat, or extra clothing.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck, chest, and waist to make breathing easier.
Treat any obvious causes such as severe bleeding by applying direct pressure or using a tourniquet when appropriate.
Reassure the person and encourage slow, steady breathing if they are conscious.
Monitor breathing and responsiveness frequently.
If the person becomes unresponsive and stops breathing normally, begin CPR.
do_not: Do not give food or drink, especially if surgery might be needed or if the person may vomit.
Do not move the person unnecessarily if you suspect spinal injury.
Do not allow the person to become chilled; avoid leaving them exposed to cold or wind.
watch_for: Worsening confusion, restlessness, or anxiety.
Decreasing level of responsiveness or loss of consciousness.
Changes in breathing pattern, such as very slow or absent breathing.
notes: Shock is a life-threatening condition; early recognition and support can help sustain life until advanced care is available.
Re-check vital signs (breathing, responsiveness, skin color) regularly.

entries.title: Stroke (Suspected)
entries.summary: Support a person who may be having a stroke when immediate medical help is not available.
steps: Use the FAST check: Face drooping on one side, Arm weakness on one side, Speech difficulty, Time of onset.
If you suspect a stroke, help the person sit or lie in a comfortable position with their head slightly raised.
Reassure the person and keep them as calm and still as possible.
Loosen tight clothing, especially around the neck and chest.
If the person is alert and able to swallow, you may offer small sips of water, but only if there is no difficulty swallowing.
If there are swallowing problems, do not give any food or drink to avoid choking.
If the person becomes drowsy or unresponsive, place them in the recovery position on their side with the mouth angled downward to allow fluids to drain.
Monitor breathing and responsiveness closely.
Record the time that symptoms first began if known, as this information will be important for medical personnel later.
Seek professional medical care as soon as it becomes available.
do_not: Do not give the person anything to eat or drink if they have trouble swallowing.
Do not let the person walk around; they could fall or worsen their condition.
Do not ignore mild or temporary symptoms; strokes can progress rapidly.
watch_for: Sudden worsening of weakness, vision, or speech.
Loss of consciousness or seizures.
Changes in breathing or color, indicating a possible need for CPR.
notes: Some stroke symptoms can be subtle at first; when in doubt, treat as a stroke.
Even if symptoms improve, a suspected stroke requires medical evaluation to prevent further damage.

entries.title: Burns (Thermal)
entries.summary: Cool and protect burned skin to limit damage and infection.
steps: Stop the burning process by removing the person from the source of heat, flame, or hot liquid.
If it is safe, remove any jewelry, belts, or tight clothing near the burned area before swelling begins.
Cool the burn immediately with cool (not ice-cold) running water for at least 20 minutes, or use clean, cool, wet cloths if running water is not available.
Avoid cooling large burns for too long if it risks causing hypothermia; focus on the burned area while keeping the rest of the body warm.
After cooling, gently pat the area dry with a clean cloth.
Cover the burn with a sterile non-stick dressing, a clean cloth, or plastic wrap applied loosely to protect from infection.
Keep the person warm and monitor for signs of shock, especially with large burns.
If blisters form, leave them intact; they help protect the underlying skin.
Seek professional care as soon as it is available, especially for burns on the face, hands, feet, groin, joints, or large areas of the body.
do_not: Do not apply ice or very cold water directly to large burns; this can cause additional tissue damage and hypothermia.
Do not apply oils, butter, toothpaste, or creams to a fresh burn.
Do not break blisters deliberately.
Do not remove clothing that is stuck to the burn; cut around it instead.
watch_for: Increasing pain, redness, or swelling after the first day.
Signs of infection such as pus, foul odor, or fever.
Signs of shock with extensive burns.
notes: Chemical and electrical burns require different specific steps; this section refers to heat and scald burns.
In remote settings, keeping burns clean and protected from dirt and insects is critical.

entries.title: Wounds and Cuts
entries.summary: Clean and dress cuts and open wounds to reduce bleeding and infection.
steps: Wash your hands or clean them with sanitizer if available before touching the wound.
If the wound is bleeding, apply direct pressure with a clean cloth or bandage until bleeding slows or stops.
Once bleeding is controlled, gently rinse the wound with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
If needed, use clean tweezers to remove visible small debris, wiping the tweezers between attempts.
Do not attempt to remove deeply embedded objects; instead, stabilize them with padding around the object.
After cleaning, gently pat the area dry with a clean cloth or sterile gauze.
Apply a thin layer of a suitable ointment if available and appropriate.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage, gauze, or clean cloth to protect it from dirt and friction.
Change the dressing at least once a day or whenever it becomes wet or dirty.
Monitor the wound daily for signs of infection.
do_not: Do not use strong antiseptics inside deep wounds unless instructed by medical guidance, as they can delay healing.
Do not blow on the wound, as this can introduce bacteria.
Do not remove large or deeply embedded objects; they may be helping to limit bleeding.
watch_for: Redness spreading outward from the wound.
Increasing pain, swelling, or warmth around the wound.
Pus, bad smell, or fever that may indicate infection.
notes: In a survival situation, keeping even small wounds clean can prevent serious infections.
If a wound is very deep, gaping, or located on a joint or face, seek professional care for possible closure when available.

entries.title: Sprains and Strains
entries.summary: Support injured joints and muscles using rest, cold, compression, and elevation.
steps: Stop the activity immediately when a joint or muscle is injured with pain, swelling, or difficulty moving.
Have the person sit or lie down and support the injured area.
Use the RICE method: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation.
Rest: avoid putting weight or stress on the injured area.
Ice: apply a cold pack or wrapped ice to the area for up to 20 minutes at a time, with at least 1 hour between applications for the first 24 hours.
Compression: wrap the area with an elastic bandage, starting away from the body and wrapping toward it, with firm but not painful pressure.
Elevation: raise the injured limb above the level of the heart if possible to reduce swelling.
After the first 48 hours, introduce gentle movement exercises as tolerated to prevent stiffness, without forcing through strong pain.
do_not: Do not apply ice directly to bare skin; wrap it in cloth.
Do not wrap compression bandages so tightly that they cause numbness, tingling, or increased pain.
Do not ignore severe or persistent pain that might indicate a fracture rather than a simple sprain.
watch_for: Inability to bear any weight on the limb.
Deformity, bone tenderness, or severe swelling suggesting a possible fracture.
Numbness or loss of circulation, such as pale or blue skin below the injury.
notes: Minor sprains typically improve within a few days; lack of improvement may indicate a more serious injury.
If a joint repeatedly sprains, it may be unstable and need medical evaluation when possible.

entries.title: Suspected Fracture
entries.summary: Immobilize broken bones and prevent further damage.
steps: Suspect a fracture if there is severe pain, swelling, deformity, inability to move or bear weight, or a grating sensation.
Keep the injured person as still as possible, supporting the injured limb in the most comfortable position.
Do not attempt to straighten the limb or push protruding bone back inside.
If there is severe bleeding, control it with direct pressure while avoiding direct pressure on protruding bones.
Prepare a splint using rigid materials such as boards, sticks, or rolled magazines and padding such as clothing or cloth.
Place padding between the limb and the splint to protect the skin and improve comfort.
Apply the splint so it immobilizes the joints above and below the suspected fracture site.
Secure the splint with bandages, cloth strips, or belts; tie knots away from the skin and not directly over the fracture.
Check circulation beyond the injury after splinting: look for normal color, warmth, feeling, and movement in fingers or toes.
Loosen the splint slightly if circulation is reduced but without removing immobilization.
Keep the person warm and monitor for signs of shock.
do_not: Do not move the person unless absolutely necessary for safety.
Do not attempt to straighten an obviously deformed limb.
Do not place a splint so tight that it cuts off circulation.
watch_for: Loss of pulse, feeling, or movement below the injury.
Increasing pain or swelling despite immobilization.
Signs of shock, especially with fractures of large bones like the thigh.
notes: In remote settings, proper splinting helps reduce pain and prevents further damage to blood vessels and nerves.
Open fractures, where bone is visible through the skin, have a high risk of infection and need medical care as soon as available.

entries.title: Head Injury (Minor to Moderate)
entries.summary: Monitor and care for a person with a non-penetrating head injury.
steps: If the person has had a blow to the head, first ensure the scene is safe.
Ask about what happened and observe for confusion, headache, dizziness, nausea, or brief loss of consciousness.
If the person is awake and responsive, keep them still and seated or lying down.
Monitor their level of alertness; check if they can answer simple questions correctly.
Apply a cold pack wrapped in cloth to any swollen area to reduce pain and swelling.
Advise rest and avoidance of physical activity or tasks that require intense concentration for at least 24 hours.
Check periodically for worsening symptoms such as repeated vomiting, increasing headache, confusion, or difficulty walking.
If the person falls asleep, wake them periodically to ensure they can be roused and are coherent.
Seek professional evaluation as soon as it is practical, especially if symptoms persist.
do_not: Do not allow the person to return quickly to strenuous activity or sports after a head injury.
Do not give alcohol or sedating medications.
Do not move the person if you suspect neck or spine injury unless they are in danger where they are.
watch_for: Repeated vomiting or worsening headache.
Confusion, slurred speech, or unusual behavior.
Weakness or numbness in limbs, seizures, or unequal pupil size.
notes: Even a mild concussion can have serious effects; rest and observation are important.
Any sign of deterioration after a head injury should be treated seriously.

entries.title: Eye Injury
entries.summary: Protect and care for eyes exposed to chemicals, debris, or trauma.
steps: If a chemical has splashed into the eye, begin flushing immediately with clean water.
Hold the eyelids open and pour water slowly from the inner corner of the eye outward to avoid contaminating the other eye.
Continue flushing for at least 15 minutes or longer if the person still feels burning or irritation.
If a small particle such as dust is in the eye, encourage blinking to help tears wash it out.
If the particle does not flush out, gently rinse the eye with clean water.
If there is an object embedded in the eye or a penetrating injury, do not attempt to remove it.
Stabilize a penetrating object by placing bulky padding around it without pressing on the eye.
Cover both eyes with clean dressings or a loose cloth to reduce eye movement; eyes move together, so covering both helps.
Keep the person as still as possible and seek professional care as soon as available.
do_not: Do not rub the eye; this can cause further damage.
Do not use tools or fingers to dig around in the eye for objects.
Do not apply pressure directly to a penetrating eye injury.
watch_for: Persistent pain, redness, or blurred vision after flushing.
Discharge, swelling, or extreme sensitivity to light.
Any change in vision such as double vision or loss of part of the visual field.
notes: Chemical burns to the eye are time-critical; immediate and prolonged flushing is the most important step.
Eye injuries can worsen quickly; protect the eye and limit movement until medical care is available.

entries.title: Heat Exhaustion
entries.summary: Treat early heat-related illness before it progresses to heat stroke.
steps: Recognize symptoms such as heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, headache, nausea, or muscle cramps.
Move the person to a cooler place, preferably in the shade or a well-ventilated shelter.
Have the person lie down with legs slightly raised if they feel faint.
Remove or loosen excess clothing to allow heat to escape.
Offer cool water or an electrolyte drink in small, frequent sips if the person is fully alert.
Apply cool, wet cloths to the skin, especially on the neck, armpits, and groin.
Fan the person to increase evaporation and cooling.
Allow the person to rest until they feel fully recovered and avoid heavy exertion for the rest of the day.
Watch for any signs of worsening condition that could indicate heat stroke.
do_not: Do not give very large amounts of water all at once; this may cause nausea or vomiting.
Do not give caffeinated or alcoholic drinks, which can worsen dehydration.
Do not ignore confusion, loss of coordination, or very high body temperature; these are serious warning signs.
watch_for: Confusion, slurred speech, or seizures.
Hot, dry skin or cessation of sweating despite heat.
Collapse, loss of consciousness, or inability to drink.
notes: Heat exhaustion is a warning stage; early treatment can prevent heat stroke.
In hot environments, schedule rest periods in the shade and maintain regular hydration.

entries.title: Heat Stroke
entries.summary: Rapidly cool a person with life-threatening overheating.
steps: Recognize signs of heat stroke: very high body temperature, confusion, agitation, hot skin that may be dry or still sweating, rapid pulse, or loss of consciousness.
Move the person immediately to the coolest available place, out of direct sun.
Remove excess clothing to allow maximum skin exposure to cooling.
Cool the person rapidly using any available methods: wet the skin with cool water, apply wet cloths, or immerse in cool (not ice-cold) water if safe and feasible.
Apply cold packs or wet cloths to the neck, armpits, and groin, which are areas of high blood flow.
Fan the person continuously to increase evaporation and heat loss.
If the person is awake and able to swallow safely, give small sips of cool water but do not delay cooling efforts.
Place an unresponsive person in the recovery position, ensuring the airway remains open.
Monitor breathing and responsiveness constantly; be ready to begin CPR if breathing stops.
Continue active cooling until the person’s condition improves or advanced medical care is available.
do_not: Do not leave the person alone while their condition is unstable.
Do not give large amounts of fluid to an unconscious or semi-conscious person.
Do not use alcohol rubs on the skin for cooling.
watch_for: Seizures, which may occur due to high body temperature.
Vomiting, which can threaten the airway if the person is unresponsive.
Signs of shock or organ failure such as worsening confusion or rapid deterioration.
notes: Heat stroke is a medical emergency; rapid and aggressive cooling can save a life.
Continue monitoring even after the person appears improved, as heat stroke can have delayed effects.

entries.title: Hypothermia
entries.summary: Warm a person whose body temperature is dangerously low.
steps: Recognize hypothermia signs: intense shivering, slurred speech, confusion, clumsiness, slow breathing, or drowsiness.
Move the person to a sheltered, dry location away from wind and cold.
Gently remove wet clothing and replace it with dry layers if available.
Wrap the person in warm blankets, sleeping bags, or dry clothing, covering the head and neck but not the face.
Use body-to-body warmth by sharing a sleeping bag or blanket if safe and appropriate.
Provide warm, sweet drinks if the person is fully awake and able to swallow safely.
Warm the core (chest and abdomen) first; keep hands and feet covered but avoid direct heat on extremities.
Handle the person gently, as sudden movement can trigger heart rhythm problems in severe hypothermia.
Monitor breathing and responsiveness, and be prepared to start CPR if breathing stops.
do_not: Do not rub or massage cold limbs; this can damage tissues and push cold blood back to the heart.
Do not give alcohol, which increases heat loss and impairs judgment.
Do not expose the person to direct intense heat (such as a fire or very hot water) on cold skin.
watch_for: Shivering that stops abruptly, which may indicate worsening hypothermia.
Increasing confusion, drowsiness, or inability to respond.
Very slow, shallow breathing or weak pulse.
notes: Mild hypothermia can often be reversed with shelter, dry clothing, and warm drinks.
Severe hypothermia is life-threatening and requires gentle handling and prolonged warming efforts.

entries.title: Dehydration
entries.summary: Recognize and treat dehydration from heat, illness, or lack of water.
steps: Recognize mild to moderate dehydration: thirst, dry mouth, dark yellow urine, headache, dizziness, or fatigue.
Encourage the person to rest in a cool, shaded location.
Provide clean water or an oral rehydration solution in small, frequent sips.
If an electrolyte drink is not available, use a solution made from clean water with a small amount of salt and sugar if you know a safe recipe.
Continue offering fluids slowly even if the person feels nauseated, as tolerated.
Advise the person to avoid heavy exertion until hydration is restored and they feel normal again.
Monitor urine output; adequate hydration usually produces light-colored urine.
If vomiting or diarrhea is present, increase fluid intake and consider oral rehydration solutions if available.
do_not: Do not give very large amounts of fluid at once, which can cause vomiting.
Do not ignore signs of severe dehydration such as very little or no urine, extreme dizziness, or confusion.
Do not rely only on caffeinated or sugary drinks; they may worsen dehydration if used alone.
watch_for: No urination for 8 hours or more.
Rapid heartbeat, sunken eyes, or very dry mouth.
Confusion, irritability, or lethargy suggesting severe dehydration.
notes: Preventing dehydration is easier than treating it; drink regularly in hot or physically demanding conditions.
In survival situations, prioritizing safe drinking water is critical for ongoing health.

entries.title: Asthma Attack
entries.summary: Assist a person having breathing difficulty due to asthma.
steps: Recognize signs of an asthma attack: wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and difficulty breathing.
Help the person sit upright in a comfortable position; leaning slightly forward with arms supported can make breathing easier.
Encourage slow, steady breathing in through the nose and out through the mouth.
If the person has a prescribed reliever inhaler, bring it to them and help them use it as directed.
Common guidance is to take one puff, breathe it in slowly and deeply, and hold the breath for several seconds if possible.
Wait a short period, then repeat as needed up to the number of puffs recommended in their asthma plan, allowing a few breaths between puffs.
Keep the environment calm; anxiety can worsen breathing difficulty.
Remove or move away from triggers such as smoke, dust, or strong odors.
If symptoms do not improve or worsen, continue supportive breathing exercises and seek advanced care as soon as it is available.
do_not: Do not leave the person alone while they are in distress.
Do not force the person to lie down flat; this can make breathing more difficult.
Do not allow smoking or exposure to smoke near the person.
watch_for: Increasing difficulty speaking in full sentences.
Bluish color of lips or fingertips, indicating lack of oxygen.
Extreme fatigue, confusion, or collapse.
notes: People with asthma often know their own action plan; ask them what usually helps and support them in following it.
If you are unsure whether it is asthma or another breathing problem, treat it as serious and focus on calming and supporting breathing.

entries.title: Low Blood Sugar (Hypoglycemia)
entries.summary: Help a person with suspected low blood sugar, especially if they have diabetes.
steps: Recognize symptoms: shakiness, sweating, hunger, irritability, confusion, headache, or sudden weakness.
If the person is alert and able to swallow, offer a fast-acting sugar source such as juice, regular soda, honey, sugar, or candy.
Encourage the person to sit or lie down to prevent injury if they become dizzy.
After 10–15 minutes, reassess symptoms; if they still feel unwell, give another small portion of fast-acting sugar.
Once they begin to feel better, follow with a longer-acting carbohydrate food if available, such as crackers or bread.
Encourage the person to rest until they feel normal and steady.
If they have diabetes and know their usual correction routine, support them in following it when they are thinking clearly again.
do_not: Do not give food or drink to someone who is unconscious or unable to swallow safely.
Do not assume confusion or unusual behavior is just emotional; it may be low blood sugar.
Do not give large amounts of food too quickly; this may cause vomiting.
watch_for: Worsening confusion or inability to respond appropriately.
Loss of consciousness or seizures.
Lack of improvement after repeated sugar intake in a conscious person.
notes: If you know the person uses insulin, low blood sugar is a possible emergency cause of sudden symptoms.
When in doubt between high and low blood sugar, small amounts of sugar are safer than doing nothing if the person is conscious.

entries.title: Food Poisoning and Diarrhea
entries.summary: Manage vomiting and diarrhea and prevent dangerous dehydration.
steps: Recognize signs: nausea, vomiting, loose or frequent stools, stomach cramps, and sometimes fever.
Encourage rest in a comfortable position, preferably near a toilet or improvised container for vomiting.
Offer small sips of clean water frequently; if tolerated, gradually increase the amount.
If available, use oral rehydration solutions or electrolyte drinks to replace lost salts.
Avoid solid food until vomiting slows; then reintroduce bland foods like rice, bread, or crackers as tolerated.
Encourage hygiene: wash hands and clean surfaces to prevent spreading illness to others.
Monitor for signs of dehydration such as very little urine, dark urine, dizziness, or dry mouth.
If there is blood in vomit or stool, high fever, or severe abdominal pain, consider the illness more serious and seek medical care when possible.
do_not: Do not force food or large volumes of fluid when the person is actively vomiting.
Do not give anti-diarrheal medications without medical advice if there is high fever or blood in the stool.
Do not ignore severe or prolonged symptoms, especially in children or older adults.
watch_for: Persistent vomiting that prevents keeping fluids down.
No urination for many hours or very dark, concentrated urine.
Confusion, weakness, or fainting that may indicate severe dehydration.
notes: Mild food poisoning usually resolves on its own, but dehydration can become dangerous if fluids are not replaced.
Safe food handling and clean water are key to preventing many gastrointestinal illnesses.

entries.title: Fever Management
entries.summary: Support a person with elevated body temperature from illness.
steps: Recognize fever by warm or hot skin, sweating, chills, headache, or feeling unusually hot or cold.
Encourage the person to rest and limit physical activity.
Keep clothing light and breathable; add or remove layers to maintain comfort.
Offer plenty of fluids such as water, herbal teas, or broths to prevent dehydration.
Use cool, damp cloths on the forehead, neck, or wrists to provide comfort if desired.
Monitor for other symptoms such as rash, severe headache, difficulty breathing, confusion, or pain.
If fever persists for several days, becomes very high, or is accompanied by alarming symptoms, seek medical care when accessible.
do_not: Do not over-bundle the person in heavy blankets; this can raise body temperature further.
Do not give alcohol to lower fever.
Do not ignore difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe neck stiffness, as these may indicate serious illness.
watch_for: Changes in mental state such as confusion, delirium, or unresponsiveness.
Very high fever that does not improve with cooling and fluids.
Signs of dehydration or severe weakness.
notes: Fever is a common response to infection and not always dangerous by itself.
Keeping the person comfortable and hydrated is the primary focus in basic first aid.

entries.title: Preventing Wound Infection
entries.summary: Keep wounds clean and protected to avoid infection.
steps: Wash your hands or clean them with sanitizer before touching any wound or dressing.
Clean new cuts and scrapes promptly with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Cover wounds with clean, dry dressings or bandages to protect them from dirt and insects.
Change dressings daily or whenever they become wet, dirty, or loose.
Check the wound each time you change the dressing for signs of infection.
Keep the area around the wound clean and dry.
Encourage the injured person to avoid scratching or picking at scabs.
do_not: Do not leave deep or dirty wounds open and unattended.
Do not reuse dirty dressings if clean materials are available.
Do not apply unknown substances or unclean materials directly to open wounds.
watch_for: Redness spreading outward from the wound.
Increased pain, swelling, or warmth.
Pus, bad odor, or fever.
notes: Good wound care significantly reduces the risk of serious infection in survival situations.
If signs of infection appear, continue cleaning and protecting the wound and seek medical help when possible.

entries.title: Heat and Hydration Prevention
entries.summary: Reduce the risk of heat illness by staying cool and hydrated.
steps: Drink water regularly throughout the day, not just when you feel very thirsty.
Increase fluid intake when working, hiking, or exercising in hot weather.
Wear lightweight, loose-fitting, and light-colored clothing to reflect sunlight.
Use hats, scarves, or improvised head coverings to shade the head and neck.
Plan strenuous activities for cooler times of day, such as early morning or late evening.
Take frequent breaks in the shade or a cool shelter.
Avoid heavy meals and alcohol in high heat, as they can increase heat stress.
Monitor yourself and others for early signs of heat exhaustion, such as excessive sweating or dizziness.
do_not: Do not rely solely on thirst as a guide for fluid needs in very hot conditions.
Do not ignore early symptoms of heat illness.
Do not wear heavy, dark clothing in direct sun if alternatives are available.
watch_for: Headache, fatigue, or irritability indicating early heat stress.
Reduced sweating or very dark urine suggesting dehydration.
Any signs of heat exhaustion or heat stroke.
notes: Prevention is especially important when medical help may be far away.
Adjust your pace and workload to match the conditions and your fitness level.

entries.title: Cold Weather and Exposure Prevention
entries.summary: Stay warm and dry to prevent hypothermia and frostbite.
steps: Dress in layers, with an inner layer that wicks moisture, an insulating middle layer, and a wind or waterproof outer layer.
Keep your head, neck, hands, and feet covered with hats, scarves, gloves, and warm socks.
Avoid cotton next to the skin in very cold conditions; it holds moisture and increases heat loss.
Change out of wet clothing as soon as possible, especially socks, gloves, and base layers.
Stay as dry as you can by using waterproof coverings and avoiding sitting directly on cold ground or snow.
Avoid excessive sweating by adjusting your pace and removing a layer if you become too warm.
Seek shelter from wind and precipitation whenever possible.
Eat regular meals and drink warm fluids if available to maintain energy and body heat.
do_not: Do not ignore shivering; it is an early sign that your body is losing heat.
Do not allow boots or clothing to stay soaked for long periods.
Do not sleep directly on bare ground; use insulating materials under your body.
watch_for: Numbness, tingling, or pale skin in fingers, toes, nose, or ears.
Uncontrolled shivering or confusion.
Slurred speech or clumsiness indicating developing hypothermia.
notes: Proper preparation for cold conditions can prevent many life-threatening situations.
Even in cool, damp weather above freezing, hypothermia can occur if clothing is wet and wind is strong.

entries.title: Safe Food and Water
entries.summary: Reduce the risk of illness from contaminated food and water.
steps: Whenever possible, drink water from trusted, clean sources.
If the safety of water is uncertain, boil it at a rolling boil for at least 1 minute (3 minutes at high altitude) before drinking.
Cool boiled water before storing it in clean, covered containers.
Avoid letting stored water sit uncovered where insects or debris can enter.
Cook food thoroughly, especially meat and eggs, until there is no visible pink or raw center.
Keep raw and cooked foods separate to avoid cross-contamination.
Wash or peel fruits and vegetables when possible.
Discard foods that smell bad, look moldy, or have unusual texture or color.
Clean cooking surfaces and utensils with hot water and soap or ash and water if nothing else is available.
do_not: Do not drink untreated water from rivers, lakes, or puddles if you can avoid it.
Do not eat food that has been left out in the heat for a long time.
Do not consume food from bulging or heavily damaged containers.
watch_for: Signs of gastrointestinal illness such as vomiting, diarrhea, or cramps.
Cloudy or foul-smelling water that may indicate contamination.
Insects, rodent droppings, or other contamination around food storage areas.
notes: In survival situations, the choice may be between drinking untreated water or risking dehydration; consider boiling or filtering whenever possible.
Good sanitation practices greatly reduce the risk of food- and waterborne diseases.

entries.title: General Disease Prevention
entries.summary: Use hygiene and simple habits to lower the risk of infections.
steps: Wash your hands frequently with soap and clean water, especially before eating and after using the toilet.
If soap is not available, use alcohol-based sanitizer or ash with water as a last resort.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Cover your mouth and nose with your elbow or a cloth when coughing or sneezing.
Keep living and sleeping areas as clean and well-ventilated as possible.
Dispose of waste and garbage away from living areas and water sources to reduce pests.
Avoid close contact with people who show signs of contagious illness when possible.
Maintain adequate rest, hydration, and nutrition to support your immune system.
do_not: Do not allow garbage and food scraps to accumulate near sleeping areas.
Do not share personal items like toothbrushes or utensils if illness is circulating.
Do not ignore sanitation in temporary or outdoor shelters; infection risk can increase quickly.
watch_for: Clusters of people developing similar symptoms, suggesting spread of infection.
Sudden changes in health after contact with sick individuals.
Signs of serious illness such as difficulty breathing, persistent high fever, or rash with fever.
notes: Simple hygiene measures are often the most effective tools in preventing disease outbreaks in group settings.
In resource-limited environments, prioritizing clean water and waste management is crucial.

entries.title: Environmental Awareness
entries.summary: Avoid bites and stings by being aware of local wildlife hazards.
steps: Learn which venomous snakes, spiders, and insects are common in the area if possible.
Avoid placing hands or feet where you cannot see, such as under rocks, in tall grass, or inside holes.
Use a stick or tool to move logs or rocks instead of using bare hands.
Wear boots, long pants, and gloves when walking or working in areas with snakes or thorny plants.
Shake out shoes, clothing, and bedding before use to remove hidden insects or small animals.
Keep sleeping areas off the ground if possible and use nets or covers to reduce contact with insects.
Store food securely to avoid attracting animals and insects.
Stay on clear paths when possible rather than walking through thick vegetation.
do_not: Do not try to handle or provoke snakes or unknown animals.
Do not put your hands or feet into crevices or holes without checking first.
Do not leave food scraps or open containers near sleeping areas.
watch_for: Snake or insect nests, burrows, or frequent sightings in one area.
Increased insect activity around standing water or waste.
Any bites or stings that cause rapid swelling, difficulty breathing, or widespread rash.
notes: Prevention of bites and stings is easier and safer than treating them after they occur.
If a bite or sting does occur, remain calm, limit movement, and seek further guidance from appropriate first-aid instructions or medical care.
